title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The Recipient will reduce threats to Sumatran tiger, tiger prey and habitat, in particular from poaching and trafficking, through focused and practical actions in and around the Kerinci Seblat landscape. This will be done by: (a) facilitating the operation of patrol and survey units in conduct of field patrols in the Park and adjoining buffer zone forests; (b) responding directly or facilitating activities to stop encroachment and conversion of tiger habitat in the Park and adjoining protected forests; (c) mitigating human-tiger and other human-wildlife conflicts to protect both wildlife and forest-edge communities thereby reducing revenge killings and demonstrating a commitment to strengthening livelihoods of local people; (d) educating forest edge communities and local decision makers, including police, regarding species and habitat conservation in the course of routine program field activities and support advocacy, campaigning and other activities by local NGOs; (e) supporting and extending development of a cadre of highly-skilled national park rangers and other young park officers and working to build the capacity of young NGO partners to support conservation of tigers and their habitat; and (f) facilitating first steps towards development of a landscape-level approach to conservation and protection of endangered species in a multi-jurisdiction Tiger Conservation Landscape.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Population monitoring for the long-term survival of Sumatra Rhino in Bukit Barisan Selatan and the Javan Rhino in Ulung Kulon

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to design, test and implement a scientifically robust long-term population monitoring protocol for accurately and reliably assessing the changes in population size and distribution for the Sumatran rhino population in Bukit Barisan Selatan and the Javan rhino in Ujung Kulon National Parks. This will be done by: (a) obtaining a reliable occupancy rate, distribution map and estimation of population size and structure for Sumatran rhinos in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park; (b) obtaining a reliable estimation of population size and structure for Javan rhinos in Ujung Kulon National Park; and (c) developing a method for long-term rhino monitoring based on results obtained during the 2012-2013 surveys in Bukit Barisan Selatan and Ujung Kulon National Parks...Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) implement a two-phase occupancy/capture-mark-recapture survey in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park; (2) identify rhino individuals through genetic analyses of fecal samples; (3) carry out a statistical analysis of the occupancy and capture-recapture data to obtain the estimated distribution and population size of the Sumatran rhinos in the Park; (4) implement a mark recapture survey using fecal DNA of the Javan rhino in Ujung Kulon National Park; (5) carry out genetic analyses of the fecal samples to identify Javan rhino individuals; (6) carry out statistical analysis on the Javan rhino capture-mark-recapture data to obtain an estimate of the Javan rhino population size in Ujung Kulon National Park; and (7) conduct a workshop and other associated meetings to discuss and finalize the long term monitoring protocols to be used going forward.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to design, test and implement a scientifically robust long-term population monitoring protocol for accurately and reliably assessing the changes in population size and distribution for the Sumatran rhino population in Bukit Barisan Selatan and the Javan rhino in Ujung Kulon National Parks. title.narrative: Rhinoceros & Tiger Conservation-Species Conservation Grant

description.narrative: Reversing decline of Sumatran rhinoceros population in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park: an alternative approach for conservation management practice

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Reversing decline of Sumatran rhinoceros population in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park: an alternative approach for conservation management practice

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to increase the number of rhinos at the Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park (BBSNP) source site to secure their future expansion into their historical home range. This will be done by: (a) scientifically defining an inviolate source site to secure the last remaining rhino population in the Park; (b) establishing and implementing an adaptive monitoring system to estimate the size of the rhino population and its density in the source site and determine spatial and temporal patterns of rhino distribution, habitat use and threats within the source site; and (c) developing a long-term inclusive strategy to improve the protection of the Sumatran rhino population in the source site.....Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) develop an agreement between the project partners regarding sharing, analysis and publication of historical data; (2) identify the current rhino distribution and relative population density in BBSNP, as well as evaluate factors contributing to the current distribution pattern in BBSNP; (3) develop a joint protocol on monitoring with key stakeholders; (4) provide training on the field survey monitoring protocols; (5) conduct and analyze monitoring surveys to identify the rhino population in source site; (6) conduct a threat assessment and analyze the data including identification, mapping and monitoring of all pathways in the source site, and conduct a series of community surveys to better understand and mitigate the impacts of human interventions in the source site; (7) conduct a study to analyze conservation interventions over the last ten years and compare with the decrease in the rhino population and distribution in BBS to evaluate conservation program effectiveness; and (8) organize a series of meetings with key-partners to jointly analyze and discuss the data and develop a joint strategy for future interventions by integrating existing activities such as rhino protection units, MIST and resort based management systems.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Advancing Klosss Gibbon Conservation in Mentawai Islands, Indonesia

description.narrative: This grant will strengthen survival and recovery of the endangered Klosss Gibbons on the Mentawai Islands in the Indonesian Archipelago by assessing threats to the habitat and populations of the gibbon, developing a conservation action plan, and facilitating long-term, local and multi-stakeholder conservation constituency. Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) carry out a gibbon population census in selected priority sites that have experienced rapid habitat and population decline (especially in Pagai, Sipora and Southern and Southwest Siberut); (2) carry out an analysis of primate distribution, and local and landscape level threats, and discuss the resulting status report with all relevant stakeholders in the lead up to formulation of a conservation action plan; (3) facilitate a multi-stakeholder planning workshop to develop a species conservation action plan based on the conservation status review; (4) develop an understanding of the awareness and practices of local communities bordering gibbon habitats on Pagai and Sipora islands by carrying out qualitative research using focus group discussions with community members and interviews with community leaders and local officials; (5) conduct pre and post-awareness studies in communities close to gibbon habitats and among key stakeholders; (6) prepare a communication strategy designed to raise awareness of the importance of primate conservation; (7) develop conservation awareness materials; (8) build the capacity of local communities and government to conserve primates through class room training, and on-the-job training in the field; (9) develop local gibbon conservation agreements and constitutencies; (10) develop partnerships with forest concessionaires and oil palm companies to cooperate on conduct of biodiversity assessments in support of primates and habitat protection across the islands; (11) conduct a High Conservation Value Forest (HCVF) assessment for forest areas that are threatened with conversion and p

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Living with elephants: expanding models to sustain community guarding in human-elephant conflict hotspots in Aceh Timur & Aceh Selatan conflict hotspots in Aceh Timur & Aceh Selatan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to apply human-elephant conflict mitigation techniques, that have been successful in southern Sumatra, in two HEC prone districts of Aceh Province in northern Sumatra. The project aims to develop and initiate demonstration sites for the implementation of low-cost conflict mitigation by local communities, facilitate a collaborative community-led guarding team for mitigating HEC, and introduce other income-generating initiatives by promoting effective microfinance programmes and institutions to encourage investment that will support the HEC mitigation and provide an alternative livelihood.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to maintain and improve the operation of the Seblat CRU in north Bengkulu Province and continue to assist the government and the surrounding villages in protecting large areas of forest for wildlife, around 6,865 hectares, for elephants, tigers, tapirs, and other wildlife. The project will also improve the health and welfare and management of the captive elephants at the Seblat that are part of the patrol, and continue building the capacity of mahouts (elephant caretakers) who are integral to the CRUs.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Development and evaluation of a local intelligence gathering network to better protect the elephants and other high-value mammals in Way Kambas National Park

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to develop and evaluate local intelligence-gathering network that will facilitate better protection of the parks elephants and their habitat, and monitor human-elephant conflict mitigation efforts by villagers and government agencies. Intelligence gathering would include providing information on elephant carcasses found by people while working in their fields, while legally collecting forest products, fishing, etc., word of poachers in the area, encroachment activity. This information will assist the park authorities to more effectively manage the park. Park staff will also be trained on intelligence-led patrolling and Management Information System (MIST) or its successor SMART.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Mobile Village Tiger Patrols VI: An integrated approach to tiger protection through education, conflict mitigation, improved livelihoods and law enforcement

description.narrative: This grant will work to bring tigers back to their natural carrying capacity in Bukit Baresan Selatan National Park and bring the tiger population of Bukit Balai Rejang forest to a level that is both capable of sustained breeding and compatible with the human activities legally permitted within BBR. This will be done by decreasing human-tiger conflict, decreasing poaching of tigers, and decreasing killing of tiger prey. Specifically, the Recipient will: (1) conduct human-wildlife conflict patrols; (2) conduct wildlife crimes investigations; (3) provide legal aid in wildlife crimes cases; and (4) conduct educational events to raise awareness about tiger conservation.

description.narrative: Monitoring of Javan Rhinoceros in Ujung Kulon National Park Using Camera and Video Traps

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Monitoring of Javan Rhinoceros in Ujung Kulon National Park Using Camera and Video Traps

description.narrative: This project will provide data and conservation recommendations needed in design of strategies to enhance breeding success of this critically endangered species. The Recipient will do this by: (1) conducting a video and camera-trap based survey of all possible Javan rhino habitat in Ujung Kulon National Park; (2) analyzing the data to (a) identify individual rhinos, (b) establish the minimum population size, (c) determine the sex and age structure of the population and (d) determine the location of the rhinos home ranges; and (3) conducting a Population Viability Analysis workshop to develop effective recommendations for Javan rhino conservation that have broad stakeholder support.

title.narrative: Saving the Sumatran Elephant through Encroachment Reduction and Preventing Future Deforestation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to focus on the prevention of encroachment and protection of the habitat through patrol and direct monitoring in the field, specifically, (1) the reduction of encroachment and other threats in areas with key elephant populations, and (2) an improved understanding of deforestation predictions in areas under threats of deforestation. The study area focuses on Bukit Barisan Selatan and Gunung Leuser National Parks which form part of the Barisan mountain range, a series of volcanoes up to 3,800m which lie along the entire western edge of the island of Sumatra.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: This projects objectives are as follows: (1) initiate, supervise and support community based human-elephant conflict (HEC) mitigation (CBCM) in order to decrease losses and damages caused by elephants and thus the risk of elephants getting killed or injured by frustrated and/or ruined farmers, (2) train local people in effective HEC mitigation strategies and methods in order to provide the basis for CBCM and eventually coexistence of elephants and people, and, (3) intensify education activities in order to increase the level of tolerance towards elephants in local communities and to raise awareness concerning the importance of conservation and sustainability concepts.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is, to (1) help local community (Mukim) institutions become recognized by district, provincial and national government as holding the rights and responsibilities for sustainable management of their customary forest areas throughout the Ulu Masen Forest in Aceh by 2016, (2) ensure communities surrounding the Ulu Masen Forest have the tools and capacity for the sustainable management of biodiversity within their customary forest areas by 2017, (3) ensure that Mukim institutions in five districts of Aceh provide community-level governance of natural resources in an effective, rigorous and transparent way, by 2015, and (4) ensure that community members surrounding the Ulu Masen Forest and from all sections of society, are engaged in, and actively contributing towards, protection of the elephant habitat and populations in the Ulu Masen Forest by 2017.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Managing disease risks and improving livestock health to secure the future of the endangered Javan rhinoceros

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect the health of Javan rhinoceroses living in Ujung Kulon National Park through understanding disease dynamics and helping local farmers improve livestock management practices. This will be done by (1) strengthening local health monitoring capacity by finalizing project partner collaborations, disseminating a draft of Javan Rhino Health Guidelines, training Indonesian veterinarians and conducting a health training workshop; (2) conducting a disease survey for Hemorrhagic Septicemia and Anthrax to determine the prevalence, distribution and risk factors in 19 villages surrounding Honje Mountain; (3) conducting a case control study to determine risk factors for HS and Anthrax infection in the water buffalo population and soil samples in the UKNP region; (4) analyzing and summarizing the data; (5) training and building the capacity of local people and communities by preparing a basic livestock health and husbandry manual for farmers; (6) conducting training on good animal husbandry and livestock management practices; and (7) disseminating project findings to the Government of Indonesia, key partners, policy makers and the scientific community.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) facilitate routine field patrols in KSNP and adjoining buffer zone forests; (2) perform targeted forest patrols to reduce seasonal poaching; (3) maintain forest-edge community relationships so that information will be provided relevant to suspected crime sites; (4) support law enforcement efforts by confirming and responding to species or forest crime; (5) maintain and develop strong relationships between Tiger Protection and Conservation Unit personnel and forest-edge farmers; (6) provide support to local NGOs; (8) enforce species and habitat protection law directly within park jurisdictions or in partnership with other agencies outside the park; (9) work with local NGOs and government agencies on tiger issues; (10) provide relevant agencies with patrol data on developing threats to tiger habitat; (11) respond to wildlife emergencies; (12) carry out routine awareness activities; (13) provide information to local NGO partners and district governments on key tiger habitats; (14) involve the National Park Authority staff in program activities; (16) identify funding and opportunities for NPA ranger and manager training: and (17) provide technical support to secure pilot implementation of Law 48 on human tiger conflict mitigation in a pilot area adjoining the national park.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build institutional capacities at the provincial and district level for improved tiger conservation in Aceh by increasing tiger protection inside the forest; reducing the trade of tigers outside of the forest; and reducing retaliatory killings of tigers. Specifically, this will be done by: (1) running a two week field based training course on SMART patrolling for three field teams (four people/team); (2) conducting SMART-based patrolling; (3) presenting a five day SMART database training workshop for five technical staff from BKSDA and FFI; (4) developing a tiger crime strategy with the Aceh police and in two Ulu Masen districts, working with police to establish a small tiger crime unit; (5) supporting establishment of a local informant network through provision of training to local NGO members, community rangers and community leaders; (6) supporting establishment of a police unit specialized in investigation of trafficking in tigers; and (7) mitigating problem tiger incidents by allocating an emergency budget to enable a rapid response to the project site when a problem tiger incident occurs.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

title.narrative: Strengthening Institutional Capacities in the Leuser-Ulu Masen Tiger Conservation Landscape, Aceh

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to build institutional capacities at the provincial and district level for improved tiger conservation in Aceh by increasing tiger protection inside the forest; reducing the trade of tigers outside of the forest; and reducing retaliatory killings of tigers. Specifically, this will be done by: (1) running a two week field based training course on SMART patrolling for three field teams (four people/team); (2) conducting SMART-based patrolling; (3) presenting a five day SMART database training workshop for five technical staff from BKSDA and FFI; (4) developing a tiger crime strategy with the Aceh police and in two Ulu Masen districts, working with police to establish a small tiger crime unit; (5) supporting establishment of a local informant network through provision of training to local NGO members, community rangers and community leaders; (6) supporting establishment of a police unit specialized in investigation of trafficking in tigers; and (7) mitigating problem tiger incidents by allocating an emergency budget to enable a rapid response to the project site when a problem tiger incident occurs.

description.narrative: Piloting full adoption of a Nationally Agreed Multi-stakeholder Protocol to Mitigate Human Tiger Conflict in and adjoining Kerinci Seblat National Park, Sumatra

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to obtain full implementation of a nationally-agreed to multi-stakeholder protocol for the mitigation of human-tiger conflict in the pilot project area and to subsequently serve as an example for other districts and provinces bordering Kerinci Seblat National Park and other protected areas on Sumatra Island. This will be done by: (1) securing a formal agreement from three districts bordering Kerinci Seblat National Park in Bengkulu province for piloting multi-stakeholder task forces to mitigate human-tiger and other human wildlife conflicts, as per Forestry Ministers Instruction No. 48; (2) providing preliminary technical advice to district governments and task force partners regarding the implementation of the nationally approved Protocol for Human-Tiger Conflict Mitigation, local reporting mechanisms, chains-of-command in the field and development of locally-relevant Standard Operational Procedure(s) for responding to and mitigating human-tiger conflict; (3) with project partners, identifying appropriate national and provincial level government funding lines to secure full implementation of Forestry Ministers Instruction No. 48 on human-wildlife conflict mitigation including compensation payments to victims of human-tiger conflict; (4) building awareness at district and provincial government levels of factors triggering human-tiger and other serious human-wildlife conflicts, in particular focusing on flawed spatial planning, infrastructure development and habitat loss and degradation in areas adjoining the national park including loss of wildlife movement corridors; (5) securing shared institutional responsibility for mitigation and prevention of human-wildlife conflicts through the adoption of the P.48 Multi-Stakeholder Protocol and preparations for implementation; and (6) achieving long term financial sustainability for the project by identifying predictable central government funding for multi-agency partnerships that aim to

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to, (1) monitor elephant population distribution, densities and conservation status in Kinabatangan, (2) ensure policies based on scientific knowledge are formulated and agreed on by stakeholders for long-term elephant conservation in Sabah, and the Elephant State Action Plan is implemented, (3) reduce level of conflicts between human activities and elephants, reduce the levels of degradation and fragmentation of elephant habitat through improved land use management in human-wildlife conflict hotspots, control illegal logging, poaching and other illicit activities, reduce crop raiding by elephants in industrial plantations and community areas, (4) enhance human resource capacity and commitment to manage and conserve elephant populations in Sabah, enhance local capabilities among Malaysian conservation professionals and provide trainings to increase local knowledge about elephants, and implement environmental awareness campaigns that target elephant conservation.

The CRUs monitor wildlife and illegal activities, respond to HEC and assess approaches to mitigate the conflicts in different sites. title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to create a sense of stewardship for rhinos among the people that live close to two important rhino habitats (Ujung Kulon National Park and Way Kambas National Park). This will be done by: 1. identifying key villages and schools in the region on the eastern side of UKNP and on the western side of WKNP and obtaining approval from villages and schools leaders to give the books to families and schools; 2. producing illustrations for the book; 3. converting book illustrations to digital image format to facilitate layout of the book and purchasing ISBN and EAN numbers and completing copy-ready design and layout of the book; 4. printing 10,000 copies of the book; 5. transporting the book to the field sites; 6. distributing the book to village families (1,500 books to families around UKNP and 1,500 books to families around WKNP); 7. delivering a conservation message to children in key primary schools that the rhinos are an integral part of each park ecosystem and provide each child a book (3,000 books to 10 schools in UKNP and 3,000 books to 10 schools in WKNP); and 8. transitioning the childrens book program to local conservation partners..."

title.narrative: Long-term conservation of maleo nesting ground in North Sulawesi through nest site protection..and management

description.narrative: Long-term Conservation of Maleo Nesting Ground in North Sulawesi Through Nest Site Protection and Management. In partnership with Wildlife Conservation Society, this project will improve the global conservation status of the maleo by ensuring the long-term protection of nesting sites in and around Bogani Nani Wartabone National park. Specific activities include: (1) post wildlife guards at the four known nesting grounds to ensure safe hatching of eggs; (2) increase support from the local community by creating educational activities about maleo conservation with local community members; (3) build protected structures to protect nests from extreme weather events; (4) work with wildlife guards to develop additional plan of action in the event of extreme weather , such as moving hatcheries to higher ground.

description.narrative: Reintroduction project for rehabilitant orangutans in west kalimantan, Indonesia

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this program is to identify suitable, safe release sites for rehabilitated animals where they can contribute to development of the wild orangutan population. This will be done by: 1) carrying out meetings and workshops with stakeholders on project planning; 2) carrying out education and outreach activities in schools and gathering places of local people; 2) exploring and promoting alternative livelihoods through socio-economic surveys to identify activities that exploit natural resources of the potential release sites; 3) identifying long term sustainable financing strategies that comply with IUCN and national laws; 3) holding meetings and workshops with government stakeholders to win their political and institutional support; 4) establishing a working plan with the BKSDA for project activities; 5) establishing a permanent reintroduction site; 6) building a habituation enclosure and other necessary infrastructure for the site; 7) collecting socio-ecological and behavioral data on the wild population of orangutans in the release area; 8) providing pre-release training to the re-introduction candidate orangutans; 9) assessing the suitability of the candidate orangutans by determining their behavioral condition; 10) establishing criteria for selection of the orangutans to be reintroduced to the wild; 11) developing and implementing a disease risk assessment and health risk analyses to identify all potential diseases that might face the released orangutans and establishing proper preventive medical treatment and pre-release screening protocols that aim to minimize the risk of transmission of diseases to wild populations; 12) carrying out a genetic assessment on each orangutan being considered for release; 13) selecting at least 3 rehabilitated orangutans from the IAR center for release as a pilot; 14) implanting each orangutan to be released with a VHF transponder; and 15) monitoring the movements of the released orangutans through radio tracking.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection of endangered ape populations in sabangau, Central Kalimantan: An integrated conservation-research program in partnership with local communities.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to effectively conserve the orangutans and gibbons of the Sabangau and to use lessons learnt to improve prospects for orangutan and gibbon conservation in other areas. This will be done by: 1. damming nine illegal logging canals within the NLPSF (Natural Laboratory Peat-Swamp Forest) to prevent fires; 2. suppressing dry-season forest fires through active firefighting in NLPSF; 3. creating eight permanent fire-fighting bores to allow immediate water access in areas away from surface water; 4. preventing illegal activities in NLPSF, including logging and hunting of protected species, through forest patrols, conducted on 15 days each month; 5. beginning the establishment of additional sustainable income options for community patrol team members through supporting trials to develop sustainable fish ponds; 6. beginning the establishment of alternative local community livelihood options by trialing CIMTROPs Buying Living Trees System; 7. assessing impacts of conservation actions on orangutan and gibbon populations; 8. assessing impacts of conservation actions on ape habitat; 9. assessing impacts of conservation actions on rapid-response indicators of ecological disturbance indicators; 10. monitoring and recording conservation initiative implementation by the Community Patrol Team; 11. increasing local scientists and villagers capacity for ape-related ecological monitoring through the OUTROP Staff Development Program; 12. increasing capacity for designing and implementing conservation programs with the community patrol team, as measured through effective design and implementation of (particularly novel) conservation and alternative livelihood initiatives; 13. increasing awareness of, and support for, orangutan and gibbon conservation within the local community through socialization activities conducted by the community patrol team; and 14. disseminating information on orangutan and gibbon conservation strategies and their impacts to

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Wildife Without Borders-Critically Endangered Animals

description.narrative: Assisting recovery of the geometric tortoise population at Elandsberg Nature Reserve, South Africa. In partnership with the University of the Western Cape, Elandsberg Farms, and CapeNature, this project will quantify the status and location of wild geometric tortoises and their major threats and Elandsberg Nature Reserve (ENR) so that authorities can implement a program to eradicate or reduce threats, and adopt management strategies to improve growth rates from harvesting eggs to eventually be released in the wild when conditions are favorable. Specific activities include: (1) Survey burnt and unburnt habitat for love and dead tortoises; (2) quantify major predators and their geographic location to inform eradication program; (3) evaluate post-fire recovery of vegetation by surveying vegetation seasonally to monitor habitat recovery; (4) use historic survey data to construct GIS maps to link tortoise distributions/numbers to habitat condition; (5) enhance survivorship of rescued animals via health monitoring and intervention by using a transmitter on rescued tortoises; (6) eliminate nest and hatchling predation of rescued females by harvesting and incubating eggs; (7) construct hatchling tables and juvenile pens in an outdoor predator-proof enclosure; (8) develop a standard diet for the tortoise hatchlings and juveniles and monitor their health and growth.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to focus on the prevention and protection of the habitat through patrol and direct monitoring in the field, specifically by the reduction of encroachment and other threats in areas with key elephant populations, and an improved understanding of deforestation predictions in areas under threats of deforestation. This will be accomplished by: 1) SMART patrolling areas with active encroachment; 2) Support to national park and legal agencies for prosecutions; 3) Assisting with national park boundary issues; 4) Working with stakeholders to understand land-use conflicts; 5) Continuous modeling of encroachment to predict likely encroachment hotspots in the future; 6) Identifying key elephant areas which are susceptible to encroachment; 7) Assisting national park authorities and UNESCO by providing data for World Heritage Site recovery Plans.

title.narrative: Saving the Sumatran Elephant through Encroachment Reduction and Preventing Future Deforestation in Bukit Barisan Selatan and Gunung Leuser National Parks

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to focus on the prevention and protection of the habitat through patrol and direct monitoring in the field, specifically by the reduction of encroachment and other threats in areas with key elephant populations, and an improved understanding of deforestation predictions in areas under threats of deforestation. This will be accomplished by: 1) SMART patrolling areas with active encroachment; 2) Support to national park and legal agencies for prosecutions; 3) Assisting with national park boundary issues; 4) Working with stakeholders to understand land-use conflicts; 5) Continuous modeling of encroachment to predict likely encroachment hotspots in the future; 6) Identifying key elephant areas which are susceptible to encroachment; 7) Assisting national park authorities and UNESCO by providing data for World Heritage Site recovery Plans.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue activities already started and implemented with support from the USFWS assistance awards no 9-G081A, I-G058 and F12AP00933 to improve Sumatran elephant and other endangered Sumatran wildlife conservation efforts by fulfilling the vital need for the above-mentioned veterinary expertise and services, throughout Sumatra. During this project, immediate support and emergency response will be provided to any government agency or NGO active in elephant and endangered wildlife conservation in Sumatra, in need of veterinary expertise in cases of injured wild elephants, rescue of trapped wild elephants, translocation of elephants, or conducting post-mortems on dead wild elephants. The project will also provide regular veterinary care and on-call emergency response to programs regularly utilizing captive elephants for elephant conservation activities such as patrols in protected elephant habitat, HEC mitigation, local community awareness, conservation education and research programs. Training will be provided to mahouts and staff in such programs about the basics of medical management of elephants, daily health care needs and elephant biology. This will ensure these elephants health and fitness, thus ensuring a continuation of elephant conservation activities.

title.narrative: Asian Elephant Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to: 1) At least 15 days per month on patrol for each RPU; 2)Appropriate action against attempts to shoot or poison elephants, in areas covered by the RPUs. No traps permitted to be placed or to remain long enough to entrap elephants (or other threatened species); 3) Apprehension of, or at least identification to the local authorities, of all suspected poachers so they can be prosecuted; 4) Continuation of the monitoring of elephant populations (and other threatened species).

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will monitor the nesting population of Jamursba Medi and Wermon Beaches, assess hatching success, maximize hatchling production through effective predator control measures, and develop the conservation program in collaboration with local community members.

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: "The purpose of this proposal is to strengthen rhino protection by improving law enforcement capabilities, eliciting cooperation from communities and preparing an action plan for long term protection. ..This will be done by: ..1) Establishing and operating three Rhino Protection Units for at least 15 days per month to detect illegal activities, removing encroachment/poaching camps and snares, helping law enforcement agencies deal with offences, recording rhino signs observed, and using data to analyze population trends; ..2) Mobilizing community support in the fringe villages of the rhino areas by holding awareness camps to elicit support for conservation of the rhinos and other mega fauna and holding separate trainings and workshops for the village heads and public representatives to mobilize institutional support; ..3) Assessing alternative livelihood mechanisms for reducing human pressure on wildlife and assessing human-wildlife conflicts in the villages surrounding the park, assessing the quantity of anthropogenic pressures on the park, assessing the impact of human pressure through Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) exercises, preparing livelihood activities for reducing human pressure and submitting the plans to the local government for use in sustainable village development;..4) Improving the management effectiveness of Gunung Leuser National Park by providing additional training on patrolling, crime detection, and law enforcement, identification of the signs of wild animals, and the use of GPS and GIS techniques; and..5) Developing long term conservation action plans needed to ensure the survival of fragmented rhinoceros populations. Project data will be used to develop site specific actions needed to improve protection and management. Forest and conservation experts will be engaged to analyze the RPU field data, community dependency, and PRA data for village level conservation and to develop site specific conservation plans. Three district level and one pr

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Increasing conservation impact in four priority Sumatran tiger landscapes

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to greatly improve the management systems that operate in five national parks that cover 3.16 million hectares. This will be done by introducing the globally- recognized Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) to assess protected area management effectiveness (in 2014 and retrospectively in 2011). It will use METT to identify management constraints and priority needs that will be addressed in subsequent strategic plans. The project will also review the current implementation of SMART in each national park, identify areas for improvement, which will be addressed through refresher training, and improve coordination and sharing of experiences between national parks and with the central government. Specifically, the project will (1) facilitate the active involvement of the Ministry of Forests and/or HarimauKita in 4 tiger landscapes; (2) conduct a gap analysis of the 4 tiger landscapes; (3) develop a strategy document for future tiger activities in each landscape; (4) train 20 masters trainers in METT; (5) conduct 10 METT analyses; (6) identify management capacity through baseline METT assessments of the parks; (7) train 15 master trainers on SMART; (8) train 40 rangers in SMART patrolling; and (9) identify law enforcement needs in each of the parks. ."

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection and Conservation of Sumatran tiger in Kerinci Seblat National Park, Sumatra

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to secure and maintain ongoing recovery of Sumatran tiger numbers in Sumatras largest protected area through the conservation and effective protection of wild Sumatran tigers, prey and habitat through reduction of current levels of threat to Sumatran tiger from highly organized tiger poaching and trade cartels, through focused and practical actions in a national park that forms the 5,400 sq. mile core of the Level One Kerinci Tiger Conservation Landscape...This will be done by: (1) securing Sumatras most important tiger population through effectively combating poaching and trafficking of Sumatran tiger and poaching of protected prey species; (2) responding directly or facilitating activities to address threat to tiger habitat including illegal.logging and forest conversion in KSNP and adjoining protected forests; (3) mitigating human-tiger and other human-wildlife conflicts to protect both wildlife and forest edge communities, reduce the threat of revenge or pre-emptive killings and demonstrate a commitment to protecting livelihoods of local people in areas where tigers frequently move in or through park-edge farmland; (4) educating forest-edge communities and local decision makers including police regarding species and habitat conservation in the course of routine program field activities; (5) providing technical support and guidance to local NGO partners and working with the National Park Authority and other stakeholders, in particular Indonesia National Police Authority (POLRI), to address threats to tigers in and around Kerinci Seblat National Park from organized trade cartels; and (6) assessing progress in securing practical implementation of the Minister of Forestrys Instruction Number 48 regarding multi-stakeholder conflict mitigation teams funded through the central government and drafting the next steps to secure similar agreements in other park-edge districts and provinces.."

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: A timely reassessment of conservation status and population baseline for the sumatran rhinoceros in the Ulu Masen Landscape, Aceh Province, Indonesia.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to provide the Government of Indonesia and relevant partners with the most recent status of Sumatran rhinoceros in Ulu Masen as a baseline for a long-term exclusive strategy to secure it in this landscape. This will be done by: (1) conducting a partner meeting and compiling and verifying data to model the most suitable habitats for Sumatran rhino in Ulu Masen; (2) conducting a desktop analysis to produce a predictive map of rhino occurrence; (3) developing a rhino survey protocol and conducting technical training in the implementation of the protocol; (4) carrying out a detection/non-detection rhino field survey; (5) analyzing the field data (using PRESENCE) to obtain unbiased estimates of the factors that influence Sumatran rhino occupancy within the predicted best suitable habitats in the Ulu Masen landscape; and (6) conducting a strategic meeting to formulate future direction of Sumatran rhino conservation the Leuser-Ulu Masen mega landscape.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Rhino & Tiger Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue to protect Sumatran rhinos, as well as other megafuana in Way Kambas National Park. This will be done by: (1) operating five RPUs in the park for at least 15 days per month; (2) allowing no traps to be placed in the park or to remain long enough to entrap rhinos, tigers, elephants or tapir; (3) apprehending, or at least identifying to the local authorities, all suspected poachers so they can be prosecuted; (4) continuing monitoring of populations of rhino, elephant, tapir, tiger, and other endangered species; (5) continuing coordination with the managed breeding center in Way Kambas to create an integrated intensive management area for Sumatran rhino; and (6) conducting training for other protection units (both for rhino and other threatened species), especially in Gunung Leuser National Park.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of Bukit Baresan Selatan through improved law enforcement and..reduced human-tiger conflict

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to decrease tiger and prey poaching, and deforestation by catalyzing a stronger law enforcement response from the BBS park staff via training, equipping and other support and to decrease human-tiger conflict in BBS/BBR (Bukit Balai Rejang) through specialized tiger-conflict mitigation teams. Specifically this will be done by (1) analyzing tiger relevant data from historical MIST/SMART patrolling of tiger; (2) establishing tiger patrol teams to prevent, investigate and prosecute wildlife and forest crimes consisting of a minimum of two government forest rangers, one local community ranger representative and WCS staff (one patrol leader and one field staff); (3) training a patrol team (GPS, SMART, etc); (4) conducting patrolling using SMART for 15 days per month in the national park; (5) analyzing SMART data and redirecting patrols; (6) analyzing and publishing historical human tiger conflict (HTC) data; (7) monitoring the effectiveness of the village informant and community warden system and ensuring regular updates and information flow; (8) responding to any human-tiger conflict and human-elephant conflicts through existing mechanisms; (9) producing and disseminating public awareness materials in target areas; and (10) maintaining tiger proof enclosures to protect livestock.

title.narrative: Marine Turtle Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The recipient will assess hawksbill population size and distribution in the Derawan Archipelago through interviews and field studies, conduct an awareness campaign focused on domestic tourists, and work with souvenir shops to stop the sale of turtle shell products.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Wildife Without Borders-Critically Endangered Animals

description.narrative: This project will address the main threats to the conservation of the Indonesia Slow Loris, illegal trade and habitat loss, by improving law enforcement capacity and awareness, and increasing public awareness of the primate to reduce demand for their trade. Specific activities include: (1) mitigating the illegal trade in Slow Lorises through improved law enforcement by conducting workshops at government offices, and supporting confiscation attempts by providing assistance in species identification and medical checks; (2) reducing the demand for trade in Slow Lorises by developing and implementing a social media campaign, conducting offline awareness campaigns in local communities, and conducting awareness-raising workshops in local communities; (3) creating a Slow Loris genetic database for conservation purposes; (4) reinforcing wild populations in Halimun-Salak National Park and Batutegi Protected Forest Reserve with rehabilitated Slow Lorises; (5) increasing knowledge of Javan Slow Loris ecology, behavior, and habitat requirements by monitoring wild Lorises and constructing 12 phenology plots to collect data from.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management

title.narrative: Monitoring and Protection of Reintroduced Orangutans in the Batikap Hill Conservation Forest, Central Kalimantan, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support successful reintroduction of rescued orangutans into well-protected natural forest in synergy with local community engagement and support, thus creating a long-lasting legacy for nature conservation and poverty eradication. This will be done by: 1) undertaking daily post-release monitoring of released orangutans and providing on-site veterinary support; 2) undertaking weekly project socialization visits to people staying or working in the release area and monthly socializations in the target villages; 3) developing, socializing and ratifying a human-orangutan conflict mitigation plan; 4) developing an environmental education program for school children in the target villages; 5) assisting the villages to implement their community development plan; and 6) developing and implementing a regular conservation patrol plan in partnership with local government.

title.narrative: Great Apes Postal Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to reduce poaching, illegal logging, encroachment and other threats in key-habitat in Gunung Leuser National Park as well as trade, trafficking and possession of Sumatran orangutans. This will be done by patrolling key orangutan habitats in Gunung Leuser National Park; and enabling the collection of information on illegal trade in orangutans in order to capture, arrest and successfully prosecute poachers and traders of orangutans.

title.narrative: Saving Sumatran Orangutans through Improving and Strengthening Law Enforcement

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to reduce poaching, illegal logging, encroachment and other threats in key-habitat in Gunung Leuser National Park as well as trade, trafficking and possession of Sumatran orangutans. This will be done by patrolling key orangutan habitats in Gunung Leuser National Park; and enabling the collection of information on illegal trade in orangutans in order to capture, arrest and successfully prosecute poachers and traders of orangutans.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Great Apes Conservation Fund

description.narrative: The purpose of this proposal is to conserve Gunung Palung National Park, an important protected area for orangutans and gibbons through a program that uses health care benefits as an incentive for villagers to stop illegal logging. This will be done by: 1) carrying out low-cost reforestation of orangutan corridors; 2) carrying out a Turn Your Debt to Forest campaign that encourages villagers to repay their debt to the ASRI health clinic by providing seedlings (that will be used to reforest orangutan habitat); 3) developing alternative livelihoods for people engaged in illegal logging such as organic farming and fishing; 4) expanding the illegal logging monitoring program; and 5) developing a How-to Manual for replicating the ASRI program in other locations.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Saving the Sumatran elephant through supporting resort-based management in Bukit Barisan Selatan and Gunung Leuser National Parks to reduce encroachment and prevent future deforestation

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to address threats to the Critically Endangered Sumatran elephant by using intelligence-gathering methods to inform law enforcement efforts, conducting intensive patrols, and predicting future patterns of encroachment to ensure patrols are directed at the most critical locales. Specific project activities will include: 1) identify priority areas for patrolling via continuous analysis of remote sensing information; 2) operate patrol teams in key areas, including selection and training of team members, and data input and analysis; 3) provide legal assistance to key stakeholders regarding court cases; and 4) analyze patrol effectiveness through collaborations with the national park authority. This project will contribute to the long-term conservation of Sumatran elephants and other wildlife by assisting Indonesian authorities in improving the management of Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park and Gunung Leuser National Park, two important habitats for elephants.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Resource Management
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation and monitoring of Sumatran elephants in Bukit Tigapuluh, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support and supervise Community-Based Conflict Mitigation (CBCM) in order to decrease both loss and damages to farmers and retaliatory actions towards Critically Endangered Sumatran elephants and to monitor movements of and threats to the resident elephant population of Bukit Tigapuluh, Sumatra. Project activities will include: 1) in-house training of Elephant Conservation and Conflict Mitigation Unit teams; 2) monitoring and tracking GPS-collared elephants and their family groups to safeguard them from poaching and poisoning; 3) the re-capture of collared elephants to replace non-active collars; 4) monitoring and assessment of damages from human-elephant conflict (HEC) incidents; and 5) strengthening the existing early-warning HEC system by working closely with village leaders and authorities to provide emergency hotline accessibility and quick response of ranger teams. This project will contribute to the peaceful coexistence of people and Sumatran elephants in one of the largest remaining lowland forests in Sumatra.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Managing elephants in Aceh: Mitigating conflicts with people and protecting critical forest habitat in Ulu Masen, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the increase and survival of populations of Critically Endangered Sumatran elephants and the integrity of their habitats via a comprehensive elephant management strategy that will also benefit the rural communities of Ulu Masen. Project activities will include: 1) in collaboration with the Wildlife Conservation Society, conduct a five-day specialized training on investigatory skills; 2) collaborate with and contribute to existing anti-wildlife trafficking units in Aceh; 3) improve involvement of media in conservation law enforcement to increase public awareness by establishing a green journalist group; 4) conduct training on the SMART patrol system for three Ministry of Forestry Protection Forest Management Units (KPH); 5) provide training on the Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool for three KPH units in the Ulu Masen forest; 6) conduct two-day workshops for each KPH to review existing management plans and identify priority actions to improve management effectiveness; 7) conduct collaborative SMART patrol meetings and facilitate priority-setting; and 8) respond to and mitigate human-elephant conflicts using Conservation Response Units. The project will contribute to the long-term conservation of the Sumatran elephant by developing an anti-wildlife trafficking network and skilled investigators that will increase legal actions against perpetrators; it will increase collaboration between non-governmental organizations and law enforcement, media coverage, and institutional capacity for monitoring, patrolling, and detection of illegal activities in Aceh, Indonesia.

title.narrative: Managing elephants in Aceh: Mitigating conflicts with people and protecting critical forest habitat in Ulu Masen, Indonesia

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection of threatened megavertebrates in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park, Sumatra, Indonesia by Anti-poaching Units

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the continued operation of the seven Rhino Protection Units (RPU) in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park (BBSNP), Sumatra. RPUs, highly trained four-member patrol teams comprised of three local community members and one National Park guard, intensively patrol key areas within the Park. They will deactivate traps and snares, identify and apprehend illegal intruders and poachers, investigate crime scenes, assist with incidents of human-elephant conflict, and monitor threatened species such as the Critically Endangered Sumatran elephants and their habitat. This award will cover the salaries, equipment, transportation, and operation costs of seven RPUs in BBSNP. This project will contribute to the long-term stabilization and recovery of Sumatran elephant populations and biodiversity of the BBSNP ecosystem.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Way Kambas National Park pilot project for habitat regeneration, fire protection, and elephant conflict mitigation in Sumatra, Indonesia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to address three threats to elephant populations in Way Kambas National Park, Sumatra: 1) Loss of habitat and intentionally set fires; 2) elephant mortality due to human-elephant conflict; and 3) suspected increases in salinity in Park water sources forcing wildlife to leave the protected area in search of fresh water. The recipient will address these threats with activities that focus on regenerating and replanting forests, mitigating human-elephant conflict, and providing sources of fresh water for both wild elephants and fire suppression. Specific activities related to reforestation include: survey and identification of project site, recruitment and training of personnel, construction of project base camp and related infrastructure, survey of naturally regenerating trees in the project site with bird and bat perches installed to facilitate seed dispersal, establishment of plant nursery for propagation of food plants attractive to wild elephants, creation of a fire-management plan, purchase of firefighting equipment, creation and maintenance of fire-breaks, and provision of a dual 24-hour fire and elephant watch system. Activities related to the mitigation of human-elephant conflict include: recruitment and training of field staff for early elephant warning duty, provision of a dual 24-hour fire and elephant watch system, establishment of a village partnership for sharing responsibility of fire and elephant warning systems, and delivery of an awareness education program to the community. The recipient will monitor salinity of water sources in the Park, construct artificial ponds to collect rain water for both fire response and elephants, and monitor pond usage by wildlife with camera traps. ..This award period of performance will be one year; however the project is expected to extend over a two-year period. Pending receipt of financial and performance reports and availability of funds, the award may be extended for an additional yea

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Securing a future for Sumatran elephants at Harapan Rainforest, Sumatra, Indonesia (Phase I)

description.narrative: This project will initiate the first phase of a planned long-term Sumatran elephant conservation program in the Harapan Rainforest with the goal of establishing and conserving a viable elephant population. Project objectives include: 1) recruitment and training of project staff to establish an elephant survey and conservation team at Harapan Rainforest; 2) create a survey map and threat-assessment of the resident elephant population; 3) introduction of simple human-elephant conflict mitigation techniques to local communities; and 4) development of a site-specific elephant conservation strategy to provide effective and cost-efficient mitigation to be undertaken in the next phase.

U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection and conservation of Sumatran Tiger in Kerinci Seblat National Park, Sumatra

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce levels of threat to Sumatran tigers, especially from organized illegal poaching and trade syndicates, through focused and practical actions in and around the national park. Project will support government partners in combating poaching and organized illegal trade in Sumatran tiger and other protected species, support actions to reduce threats to tiger habitat, mitigate human-tiger and human-wildlife conflicts thus reducing revenge killings. Project will also maintain technical support to the national park authority and park police, and monitor results of activation of a multi-stakeholder Wildlife Conflict Mitigation Taskforce in Bengkulu established as a result of an earlier FWS grant.

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of Gunung Leuser National Park through improved law enforcement a reduced human-tiger conflict, Sumatra, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring tigers back to their natural carrying capacity in Gunung Leuser National Park (GLNP) and to bring the tiger population to a level that is both capable of sustained breeding and compatible with the human activities legally permitted within GLNP.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of Bukit Barisan Selatan through improved law enforcement and reduced human-tiger conflict, Sumatra, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring tigers back to their natural carrying capacity in Bukit Barisan Selatan (BBS) and to bring the tiger population of Bukit Balai Rejang (BBR) to a level that is capable of sustained breeding. This is to be done through improving and strengthening law enforcement and reducing human-tiger conflict in the BBS/BBR landscape.

title.narrative: Conservation of the tigers of Gunung Leuser National Park through improved law enforcement and reduced human-tiger conflict, Sumatra, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to bring tigers back to their natural carrying capacity in Gunung Leuser National Park (GLNP) and to bring the tiger population of GLNP to a level that is both capable of sustained breeding and compatible with the human activities legally permitted within GLNP. This is to be done through improving and strengthening law enforcement and decreasing human-tiger conflict in the GLNP landscape.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Javan Rhino protection units in Ujung Kulon National Park, Javan, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent the extinction of the Javan rhino, as well as to protect other threatened species and critical habitats within and around the national park. Project will support 15 days per month patrolling for each four-man Rhino Protection Unit (RPU), ensure that no traps are permitted to be placed or remain long enough to entrap rhinos, apprehension or at least identification to the local authorities of all suspected poachers so they can be prosecuted, monitoring of populations of rhino and other endangered mammals, and the addition of a fifth RPU to patrol and monitor the additional habitat opened up with the creation of the 5,000-hectare Javan Rhino Study and Conservation Area (JRSCA).

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Javan Rhino protection units in Ujung Kulon National Park, Javan, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent the extinction of the Javan rhino, as well as to protect other threatened species and critical habitats within and around the national park. Project will support 15 days per month patrolling for each four-man Rhino Protection Unit (RPU), ensure that no traps are permitted to be placed or remain long enough to entrap rhinos, apprehension or at least identification to the local authorities of all suspected poachers so they can be prosecuted, monitoring of populations of rhino and other endangered mammals, and the addition of a fifth RPU to patrol and monitor the additional habitat opened up with the creation of the 5,000-hectare Javan Rhino Study and Conservation Area (JRSCA).

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Developing effective markers for censuring of Sumatran and Javan rhinoceros by local researchers

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to develop microsatellite markers for both Sumatran and Javan rhinoceros species that can effectively be used by Indonesian researchers to census rhino populations, to build capacity of Indonesians with respect to numerous aspects of wildlife genetics including sample collection, DNA extraction, sequencing, genotyping, censusing, analyses, and interpretation of results to compare genomic sequences. This project should further help Indonesian researchers to conduct genetic censusing and sexing of rhinos in local laboratories, in order to monitor and manage their own rhino populations.

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection of Sumatran rhinos and other mega-fauna by anti-poaching units in Way Kambas National Park, Sumatra, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue to protect Sumatran rhinos and other mega-fauna in Way Kambas National Park. This protection will be accomplished by the Rhino Protection Units (RPUs). RPUs will patrol and survey the full extent of Way Kambas National Park, monitor rhino and threatened mega-fauna populations, curtail hunting and trapping of wildlife, minimize effects of human encroachment, raise awareness in neighboring villages, and provide conservation education and other community-based programs.

title.narrative: Long-term Conservation of Maleo Nesting Grounds in North Sulawesi through Nest Site Protection and Management

description.narrative: This project will work to address threats to the maleos and their nesting grounds. Specific objectives include: (1) Maintain protection of maleo nesting sites at the four currently managed sites in Tambun, Muara Pusian, Hungayono and Binerean; (2) Increase support from the local community and boost their enthusiasm for maleo conservation; (3) Develop partnerships for sustainable financing of maleo protection efforts.

title.narrative: Protecting Sumatran Orangutans by Preventing Forest Encroachment and Improving and Strengthening Law Enforcement in Gunung Leuser National Park

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to reduce the encroachment of people into the forest, hunting, illegal logging, and other threats in key orangutan habitat in Gunung Leuser National Park, and halt the trade/trafficking of the Sumatran orangutan. Project will support SMART patrolling of key orangutan habitat in Gunung Leuser National Park, and enable the collection of information on illegal trade in orangutans in order to capture, arrest and successfully prosecute poachers and traders of orangutans.

title.narrative: Protection of Threatened Sumatran Ape Populations and Their Habitats, and Mitigation of the Impact of Road Expansion Within Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to prevent habitat loss for gibbons and siamangs through patrols with park rangers especially near roads in areas under high threat of deforestation, support park authorities to understand the impacts of road expansion based on analysis of longitudinal studies on the population and distribution of siamang and gibbon in BBS, and use this to develop recommendations for mitigating road development impacts, and reduce poaching and trafficking of apes through targeting key poaching and wildlife trade networks in and around BBS. Project will support SMART patrols in key areas in the national park, complete analysis of gibbon/siamang data to understand impacts of road expansion, and reduce poaching and trafficking of apes.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to determine current population size and longitudinal changes within the orangutan population of the GPNP landscape to assess conservation effectiveness and target future conservation efforts, pilot the use of electronic drones as a cost effective tool for orangutan population assessments, and assess population viability and health status of orangutans using the GPNP landscape.

title.narrative: Engaging Muslim Leaders in Rhino and Tiger Conservation in Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to create a working model of conservation and religion partnerships that develop strong support among Muslim communities for the conservation of tigers and rhinos. MUIs (Indonesias most influential Muslim body) recently issued national edict on biodiversity protection, and encourage conservation NGOs working in key tiger and rhino sites to more fully integrate religious partners and perspectives into conservation activities.

title.narrative: Implementation of a systematic reintroduction programme for rehabilitant orangutans in West Kalimantan

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to continue the implementation of the conservation management strategies identified in the previous phases of the project to ensure the long-term protection of the orangutans reintroduced into this area, conduct pre- and post-release monitoring of reintroduced orangutans producing the first comprehensive behavioral ecological data of reintroduced orangutans into BBBR NP, determine and monitor forest production (via plant phenology), continue long term monitoring of wild orangutans at the site as well as populations of other wildlife present at the reintroduction site, and the potential effects of the released orangutans into this area, and obtain politico-institutional support for the reintroduction project and the reintroduction site.

title.narrative: Community-based Conservation of the Endangered Maleo in Tompotika, Indonesia

description.narrative: This project will use previously successful community-based methods to create a landscape-scale maleo conservation effort consisting of two protected nesting grounds connected by intact natural forest. In addition to scaling up field conservation efforts on behalf of Tompotika's maleos, this project will also strengthen outreach and education efforts that will reach over 1000 school children per month.

title.narrative: Strengthening Protection in Way Kambas and Bukit Barisan Selatan Antional Parks and other Indonesian Protected Areas

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to replicate and expand the highly successful law enforcement model, the Rhino Protection Unit, administered by Yayasan Badak Indonesia (YABI), on the ground. Two new RPUs will be established, one in Way Kambas National Park (WKNP) and one in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park (BBSNP). The project has the following main objective: To work with Indonesian counterparts to strengthen Protected Area (PA) management, using a multidisciplinary law enforcement team to conduct a PA evaluation, develop a plan to strengthen enforcement efforts, and provide training, expertise, and other support in implementing the plan.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION AND MONITORING OF SUMATRAN ELEPHANTS IN BUKIT TIGAPULUH, INDONESIA

description.narrative: The long-term goal of our initiative is to create and maintain a situation in which elephants and local people are able to coexist in a peaceful manner. Previous work focused on immediate aid to reduce HEC by using well trained HEC mitigation teams, monitoring and researching HEC and the resident elephants, testing HEC methods and strategies, education and awareness activities, and by initiating site-specific pilot projects and Community Based Conflict Mitigation (CBCM).

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Conservation and monitoring of Sumatran elephants in Bukit Tigapuluh, Indonesia

description.narrative: "The purpose of this project is to support and supervise Community-Based Conflict Mitigation (CBCM) in order to decrease both loss and damages to farmers and retaliatory actions towards Critically Endangered Sumatran elephants and to monitor movements of and threats to the resident elephant population of Bukit Tigapuluh, Sumatra, Indonesia. Project activities will include: 1) in-house training of Elephant Conservation and Conflict Mitigation Unit teams; 2) monitoring and tracking GPS-collared elephants and their family groups to safeguard them from poaching and poisoning; 3) the re-capture of collared elephants to replace non-active collars; 4) monitoring and assessment of damages from human-elephant conflict (HEC) incidents; and 5) further strengthening the existing early-warning HEC system by working closely with village leaders and authorities to provide emergency hotline accessibility and quick response of ranger teams. This project will contribute to the peaceful coexistence of people and Sumatran elephants in one of the largest remaining lowland forests in Sumatra. ..This award is provisionally approved for five phases or years funding, with each phase or year's funding dependent upon performance and financial management of the previous phase or year, meeting technical and financial reporting requirements, and availability of ASECF funds. "

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Developing elephant and other wildlife veterinary teaching, training, and research capacities and an elephant and wildlife ambulance at the Veterinary faculty of the Syiah Kuala University, Banda Aceh, Indonesia

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the establishment of a wildlife veterinary education program and wildlife veterinary ambulance services at the Center for Wildlife Studies, Syiah Kuala University, Banda Aceh, Sumatra. Specific activities will include: 1) conducting lectures, courses, and workshops on wildlife veterinary medicine for veterinary students and veterinarians; 2) establishing and operating a wildlife ambulance to provide veterinary services for conservation programs; and 3) identifying, developing, and establishing wildlife research projects. By ensuring the existence of elephant and wildlife veterinary expertise, this project will lead to the improved conservation of the Critically Endangered Sumatran elephant, captive Sumatran elephants working as patrols on conservation response units, and other wildlife in Sumatra, Indonesia.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund

title.narrative: Protection of Sumatran elephants and other threatened species in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park, Sumatra, Indonesia, by anti-poaching units

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the continued operation of the seven Rhino Protection Units (RPU) in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park (BBSNP), Sumatra. RPUs, highly trained four-member patrol teams comprised of three local community members and one National Park guard, intensively patrol key areas within the Park. They will deactivate traps and snares, identify and apprehend illegal intruders and poachers, investigate crime scenes, assist with incidents of human-elephant conflict, and monitor threatened species such as the Critically Endangered Sumatran elephants and their habitat. This award will cover the salaries, equipment, transportation, and operation costs of seven RPUs in BBSNP. This project will contribute to the long-term stabilization and recovery of Sumatran elephant populations and biodiversity of the BBSNP ecosystem, Indonesia.

person-name.narrative: William Jones; Colleen Holland; Julie Rice; Ry

transaction.usg:treasury-account: U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Multinational Species Conservation Fund
