title.narrative: PROTECTING SUMATRAN ELEPHANT POPULATIONS AND HABITAT THROUGH ELEPHANT RESPONSE UNITS (ERU) IN COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN WAY KAMBAS NATIONAL PARK, LAMPUNG PROVINCE, INDONESIA

description.narrative: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE INTEGRITY OF WAY KAMBAS NATIONAL PARK (WKNP) AND ITS CRITICALLY ENDANGERED POPULATION OF SUMATRAN ELEPHANTS AND TO PROMOTE HUMAN-ELEPHANT COEXISTENCE WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES. THROUGH THE DEPLOYMENT OF ELEPHANT RESPONSE UNITS (ERU) AND IN CLOSE COLLABORATION WITH WKNP AUTHORITIES AND FOREST POLICE, THIS PROJECT WILL MONITOR, MITIGATE, AND PREVENT HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC), EMPOWER LOCAL COMMUNITIES, PROVIDE CARE FOR AND MANAGEMENT OF ERU ELEPHANTS, AND DETECT AND PREVENT ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES IN AND AROUND THE PARK. ERUS EMPLOY ELEPHANTS AND THEIR SKILLED HANDLERS ALONG WITH TRAINED LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT REGULAR FOREST PATROLS TO DETECT AND PREVENT ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES, MONITOR WILD ASIAN ELEPHANT HERDS, AND MITIGATE CONFLICT BETWEEN ELEPHANTS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES. PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) EQUIPPING (FIRE EXTINGUISHERS, CAMERAS, LAPTOP AND PRINTERS, BOOTS, RAINCOATS, BACKPACKS, GPS UNITS, HEADLAMPS, RADIOS, UNIFORMS, BACKPACK SPRAYERS, MOSQUITO REPELLENT, FIRST AID SUPPLIES, RATIONS, ELEPHANT FOOD AND VITAMINS, HOSES, SACKS, AND OFFICE MATERIALS) AND OPERATING 4 ERU TEAMS AND CAMPS, TOTALING 65 STAFF AND 27 ELEPHANTS (2) ERU HABITAT PATROLS AND WILD ELEPHANT MONITORING (3) MAINTAINING GPS COLLARS ON SIX WILD ELEPHANTS, COLLECTING AND ANALYZING

title.narrative: PROTECTING SUMATRAN ELEPHANT POPULATIONS AND HABITAT THROUGH ELEPHANT RESPONSE UNITS (ERU) IN COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES IN WAY KAMBAS NATIONAL PARK, LAMPUNG PROVINCE, INDONESIA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to protect the integrity of Way Kambas National Park (WKNP) and its critically endangered population of Sumatran elephants and to promote human-elephant coexistence with local communities. Through the deployment of Elephant Response Units (ERU) and in close collaboration with WKNP authorities and forest police, this project will monitor, mitigate, and prevent human-elephant conflict (HEC), empower local communities, provide care for and management of ERU elephants, and detect and prevent illegal activities in and around the park. ERUs employ elephants and their skilled handlers along with trained local community members to conduct regular forest patrols to detect and prevent illegal activities, monitor wild Asian elephant herds, and mitigate conflict between elephants and local communities. Project activities include: (1) equipping (fire extinguishers, cameras, laptop and printers, boots, raincoats, backpacks, GPS units, headlamps, radios, uniforms, backpack sprayers, mosquito repellent, first aid supplies, rations, elephant food and vitamins, hoses, sacks, and office materials) and operating 4 ERU teams and camps, totaling 65 staff and 27 elephants; (2) ERU habitat patrols and wild elephant monitoring; (3) maintaining GPS collars on six wild elephants, collecting and analyzing resultant data, and using the data to provide immediate response by ERUs to HEC events; (4) conducting night watches along WKNP boundaries to prevent wild elephants from raiding crops; (5) constructing watch towers to assist communities with night guarding of crops: (6) training community crop guarding groups in HEC mitigation techniques; (7) providing conservation education to local communities at ERU camps and assisting local communities with alternative livelihood activities such as fish ponds and livestock fodder cultivation; (8) conducting regular forest patrols to detect and document illegal logging, remove and destroy traps, snares, and nets, drive livestock

title.narrative: CONSERVATION AND MONITORING OF SUMATRAN ELEPHANTS IN BUKIT TIGA PULUH, INDONESIA - 2

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AND SUPERVISE COMMUNITY BASED CONFLICT MITIGATION (CBCM) IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE JAMBI DEPARTMENT OF CONSERVATION OF NATURAL RESOURCES TO DECREASE BOTH LOSS AND DAMAGES TO FARMERS, RETALIATORY ACTIONS TOWARDS CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SUMATRAN ELEPHANTS, AND MONITOR MOVEMENTS OF AND THREATS TO THE RESIDENT ELEPHANT POPULATION OF BUKIT TIGAPULUH, SUMATRA, INDONESIA. THE OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT ARE TO (1) SUPPORT AND SUPERVISE CBCM TO MITIGATE HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT (HEC) AND (2) MONITOR BOTH ELEPHANTS AND HEC TO OBTAIN VITAL INFORMATION ON THREATS AND ELEPHANT LOCATIONS AND MOVEMENT TO SUPPORT CBCM AND ELEPHANT SAFEGUARDING. PROJECT ACTIVITIES ARE (1) TO PROVIDE CBCM SUPPORT AND SUPERVISION, INCLUDING TRAINING OF LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS AND PROVIDING MATERIALS AND TECHNIQUES FOR HEC MITIGATION (2) TO MONITOR AND SAFEGUARD RESIDENT ELEPHANTS USING GPS VHF TELEMETRY AND DIRECT OBSERVATIONS (3) RE CAPTURE ELEPHANTS IN ORDER TO EXCHANGE OR REMOVE WORN GPS VHF COLLARS (4) TO MONITOR HEC BY DIRECT INVESTIGATION OF ALL CONFLICTS IN THE FOCUS AREA AND (5) MAINTAIN THE ESTABLISHED EARLY WARNING SYSTEM AND INFORMATION NETWORK TO SUPPORT THE HEC MITIGATION AND ELEPHANT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES OF FIELD TEAMS, CBCM WORK GROUPS, AND LOCAL GOVERNMENT.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION AND MONITORING OF SUMATRAN ELEPHANTS IN BUKIT TIGA PULUH, INDONESIA - 2

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support and supervise Community-Based Conflict Mitigation (CBCM) in partnership with the Jambi Department of Conservation of Natural Resources to decrease both loss and damages to farmers, retaliatory actions towards critically endangered Sumatran elephants, and monitor movements of and threats to the resident elephant population of Bukit Tigapuluh, Sumatra, Indonesia. The objectives of the project are to: (1) support and supervise CBCM to mitigate human-elephant conflict (HEC); and (2) monitor both elephants and HEC to obtain vital information on threats and elephant locations and movement to support CBCM and elephant safeguarding. Project activities are: (1) to provide CBCM support and supervision, including training of local community members and providing materials and techniques for HEC mitigation; (2) to monitor and safeguard resident elephants using GPS/VHF telemetry and direct observations; (3) re-capture elephants in order to exchange or remove worn GPS/VHF collars; (4) to monitor HEC by direct investigation of all conflicts in the focus area; and (5) maintain the established Early Warning System and Information Network to support the HEC mitigation and elephant conservation activities of field teams, CBCM work groups, and local government.

THE MAIN OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE TO (1) CONTINUE WILDLIFE SPECIFIC VETERINARY EDUCATION AND TRAINING AT THE CENTER FOR WILDLIFE STUDIES AND ITS PROGRAM FOR WILDLIFE AND CONSERVATION MEDICINE AT THE VETERINARY FACULTY OF SYIAH KUALA UNIVERSITY BANDA ACEH IN COLLABORATION WITH EXPERIENCED NATIONAL AND INTERNATIONAL WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS AND (2) CONTINUE THE WILDLIFE AMBULANCE PROGRAM, WHICH PROVIDES VETERINARY EXPERTISE AND SERVICES NEEDED FOR ELEPHANT AND OTHER WILDLIFE CONSERVATION AND WELFARE PROGRAMS CONDUCTED BY GOVERNMENTAL AND NON GOVERNMENTAL INSTITUTIONS IN SUMATRA. SPECIFIC PROJECT ACTIVITIES INCLUDE (1) WEEKLY CLASSES AND LECTURES DELIVERED TO 200 STUDENTS ANNUALLY (2) ONE TO EIGHT WEEK COURSES, SEMINARS, AND HANDS ON FIELD TRAININGS FOR STUDENTS (3) OPERATION OF A WILDLIFE AMBULANCE TO PROVIDE EMERGENCY RESPONSE SERVICES AND RESCUE OF INJURED WILD ELEPHANTS (4) DELIVERY OF CONTINUING EDUCATION COURSES AND WORKSHOPS FOR CERTIFIED WILDLIFE VETERINARIANS (5) UNDERTAKING VETERINARY RESEARCH BY FACULTY AND SCIENTIFIC ST

title.narrative: CONTINUING THE DEVELOPMENT OF ELEPHANT AND OTHER WILDLIFE VETERINARY TEACHING, TRAINING AND RESEARCH CAPACITIES, AND AN ELEPHANT AND WILDLIFE AMBULANCE AT THE VETERINARY FACULTY OF THE KYIAH KUALA UNI

description.narrative: The primary goal of this project is to continue the development of regular, high-quality elephant and wildlife veterinary teaching and training at Syiah Kuala University and to provide qualified veterinary services for all wildlife conservation programs in Sumatra, Indonesia. The main objectives of this project are to: (1) continue wildlife-specific veterinary education and training at the Center for Wildlife Studies and its program for wildlife and conservation medicine at the veterinary faculty of Syiah Kuala University Banda Aceh in collaboration with experienced national and international wildlife veterinarians; and (2) continue the Wildlife Ambulance program, which provides veterinary expertise and services needed for elephant and other wildlife conservation and welfare programs conducted by governmental and non-governmental institutions in Sumatra. Specific project activities include: (1) weekly classes and lectures delivered to 200 students annually; (2) one- to eight-week courses, seminars, and hands-on field trainings for students; (3) operation of a wildlife ambulance to provide emergency response services and rescue of injured wild elephants; (4) delivery of continuing education courses and workshops for certified wildlife veterinarians; (5) undertaking veterinary research by faculty and scientific staff; (6) on-call service for conducting wildlife post mortems; (7) provision of veterinary support for elephant translocation, fitting GPS collars, and research and monitoring; (8) delivery of regular visits, veterinary support, and on-call emergency services to elephant patrol units and elephant camps; and (9) build local capacity to manage wildlife emergencies by including provincial veterinarians in wildlife ambulance field activities.

title.narrative: IMPROVING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT MITIGATION AND SECURING SUMATRAN ELEPHANT POPULATION IN ULU MASEN, SUMATRA

description.narrative: THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ENSURE THE SURVIVAL AND RECOVERY OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SUMATRAN ELEPHANT POPULATION AND THE INTEGRITY OF ITS HABITAT THROUGH A COMPREHENSIVE ELEPHANT MANAGEMENT STRATEGY AND HUMAN ELEPHANT CONFLICT MITIGATION (HEC) THAT BENEFITS THE RURAL COMMUNITIES OF ULU MASEN, ACEH, SUMATRA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES AND ACTIVITIES ARE TO (1) WORK CLOSELY WITH LOCAL STAKEHOLDERS TO MONITOR HEC, AND CREATE AN EARLY WARNING SYSTEM FOR HEC MITIGATION IN PIDIE AND PIDIE JAYA DISTRICTS BY CONNECTING RESIDENTS USING SMS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION APPS (2) FORM AND TRAIN HEC RESPONSE AND MITIGATION TEAMS IN NINE VILLAGES WITH 10 12 COMMUNITY MEMBERS ON EACH TEAM (3) INSTALL SOLAR ELECTRIC FENCING AND OR CULTIVATE UNPALATABLE PLANTS TO FORM NATURAL BARRIERS TO ELEPHANT MOVEMENT (4) PREVENT CRIME AND REDUCE POACHING IN TARGET AREAS THROUGH COLLABORATIVE PATROLS BASED ON THE SMART (SPATIAL MONITORING AND REPORTING TOOL) RESORT BASED MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (5) CONDUCT AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS ON WILDLIFE LAWS AND REDUCE THREATS TO WILDLIFE IN 30 VILLAGES AND (6) SUPPORT LAW ENFORCEMENT INSTITUTIONS AND COMMUNITY INFORMANT NETWORKS IN THREE CASES RELATED TO POACHING AND WILDLIFE TRAFFICKING.

title.narrative: IMPROVING HUMAN-ELEPHANT CONFLICT MITIGATION AND SECURING SUMATRAN ELEPHANT POPULATION IN ULU MASEN, SUMATRA

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to ensure the survival and recovery of the critically endangered Sumatran elephant population and the integrity of its habitat through a comprehensive elephant management strategy and human-elephant conflict mitigation (HEC) that benefits the rural communities of Ulu Masen, Aceh, Sumatra. Project objectives and activities are to: (1) work closely with local stakeholders to monitor HEC, and create an early warning system for HEC mitigation in Pidie and Pidie Jaya districts by connecting residents using SMS and other communication apps; (2) form and train HEC response and mitigation teams in nine villages with 10-12 community members on each team; (3) install solar electric fencing and/or cultivate unpalatable plants to form natural barriers to elephant movement; (4) prevent crime and reduce poaching in target areas through collaborative patrols based on the SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) Resort Based Management system; (5) conduct awareness campaigns on wildlife laws and reduce threats to wildlife in 30 villages; and (6) support law enforcement institutions and community informant networks in three cases related to poaching and wildlife trafficking.

title.narrative: ENHANCING SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON CONSERVATION THROUGH IMPROVED PROTECTION AND RESEARCH IN BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN NATIONAL PARK

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT PRIORITY POPULATIONS OF SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON AND THEIR HABITAT IN BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN NATIONAL PARK (BBSNP). PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) PREVENT HABITAT LOSS FOR SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON THROUGH RANGER PATROLS, WITH SPECIAL ATTENTION GIVEN TO FOREST LOCATED IN CLOSE PROXIMITY TO ROADS AND (2) IMPROVE BBSNP MANAGEMENT PLANNING FOR SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON CONSERVATION THROUGH ENHANCED RESEARCH. RESEARCH INCLUDES, BBSNP WIDE SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON SURVEYS, REGULAR MONITORING OF SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON IN THE WAY CANGUK RESEARCH STATION (INCLUDING MONITORING FOR INFECTIOUS DISEASE), CONDUCTING YEARLY FOREST COVER MONITORING, DEVELOPING SAFETY PROTOCOLS FOR SAMPLE COLLECTION (INFECTIOUS DISEASE), AND DISSEMINATION OF PROJECT RESULTS TO BBSNP AND RELEVANT STAKEHOLDERS (LOCAL AND NATIONAL).

title.narrative: ENHANCING SIAMANG AND AGILE GIBBON CONSERVATION THROUGH IMPROVED PROTECTION AND RESEARCH IN BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN NATIONAL PARK.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect priority populations of siamang and agile gibbon and their habitat in Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park (BBSNP). Project objectives include, (1) Prevent habitat loss for siamang and agile gibbon through ranger patrols, with special attention given to forest located in close proximity to roads; and (2) Improve BBSNP management planning for siamang and agile gibbon conservation through enhanced research. Research includes, BBSNP wide siamang and agile gibbon surveys, regular monitoring of siamang and agile gibbon in the Way Canguk Research Station (including monitoring for infectious disease), conducting yearly forest cover monitoring, developing safety protocols for sample collection (infectious disease), and dissemination of project results to BBSNP and relevant stakeholders (local and national).

title.narrative: COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION OF JAVAN GIBBON (HYLOBATES MOLOCH) IN CENTRAL JAVA, INDONESIA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect and restore the habitat and population of the Javan gibbon in the western part of Dieng Mountain through a collaboratively managed Essential Ecosystem Area (KEE) and a landscape restoration approach. Project objectives include, (1) Maintain biodiversity in the wider mosaic forest landscape based on sound science through restoration of forest/agroforestry corridors using arboreal mammals, such as Javan gibbon and langurs as indicator species; (2) Upscale sustainable coffee agroforests and developing sustainable value chains for biodiversity friendly coffee using a participatory market-based approach, which would potentially lead to 11 villages surrounding the area adopting village land use plans that increase forest connectivity through community forestry, agroforestry intervention and community-based protection of remnant forests, and at least 300 additional households adopt coffee agroforests and improved value chains for biodiversity friendly coffee; and (3) Participatory gazettement and collaborative management of a KEE, with the free, prior and informed consent of local stakeholders, and this would lead to a collaborative management system established for KEE.

title.narrative: COMMUNITY-BASED CONSERVATION OF JAVAN GIBBON (HYLOBATES MOLOCH) IN CENTRAL JAVA, INDONESIA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to protect and restore the habitat and population of the.Javan gibbon in the western part of Dieng Mountain through a collaboratively managed Essential.Ecosystem Area (KEE) and a landscape restoration approach. Project objectives include, (1) Maintain.biodiversity in the wider mosaic forest landscape based on sound science through restoration of.forest/agroforestry corridors using arboreal mammals, such as Javan gibbon and langurs as indicator.species; (2) Upscale sustainable coffee agroforests and developing sustainable value chains for.biodiversity friendly coffee using a participatory market-based approach, which would potentially lead to.11 villages surrounding the area adopting village land use plans that increase forest connectivity through.community forestry, agroforestry intervention and community-based protection of remnant forests, and at.least 300 additional households adopt coffee agroforests and improved value chains for biodiversity.friendly coffee; and (3) Participatory gazettement and collaborative management of a KEE, with the free,.prior and informed consent of local stakeholders, and this would lead to a collaborative management.system established for KEE.

title.narrative: PROTECTION OF SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN (PONGO ABELII) POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS IN KETAMBE, SORAYA AND SUAQ RESEARCH STATIONS IN WESTERN LEUSER ECOSYSTEM, ACEH, INDONESIA

description.narrative: The primary goal of this project is to improve the community protection system for orangutans and their forest habitat around the Ketambe, Suaq Belimbing and Soraya Research Stations by establishing and enhancing Community Patrol Teams that engage in participatory forest patrol and forest restoration. Project objectives include, (1) Training of Community Patrol Teams; (2) Equip and support Community Patrol Teams by providing the teams with basic field gear such as tents, field clothing, raincoats, GPS units, etc.; (3) Community patrols & reduce illegal activity; (4) Forest restoration in orangutan habitat; and (5) Orangutan monitoring in Ketambe and Soraya.

title.narrative: SAVING THE SUMATRAN ELEPHANT IN BUKIT BARISAN SELATAN NATIONAL PARK, INDONESIA.

description.narrative: The goal of this project is to assist Indonesian authorities in improving the management of Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park to maintain forest habitat for critically endangered Sumatran elephants and other threatened wildlife. The projects objectives focus on preventing threats and protecting habitats and elephants by: (1) strengthening national park management through the integration of SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) into Resort Based Management (RBM) to reduce forest encroachment, poaching, and other threats in key elephant areas; and (2) managing human-elephant conflict (HEC) by strengthening community participation and increasing government support. Project activities are to: (1) provide advanced training to ranger teams in enhanced SMART patrol methods; (2) provide technical assistance to seven ranger forest patrol teams; (3) conduct SMART-RBM strategy evaluations to assess the implementation of the system and ranger patrol effectiveness and strategically plan patrols to target high-risk areas; (4) mitigate HEC with a rapid-response Wildlife Response Unit; (5) establish and strengthen additional community-based HEC mitigation teams; (6) enable district government and other agencies to provide support in HEC mitigation interventions; and (7) evaluate the effectiveness of HEC intervention strategies.

title.narrative: A HOLISTIC APPROACH TO THE CONSERVATION OF PONGO PYGMAEUS IN WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to ensure the long-term protection of the critically endangered Bornean.orangutan (Pongo pygmaeus) population and their habitat in Bukit Baka Bukit Raya National Park.(BBBRNP), West Kalimantan. The project will use scientific research to instruct conservation actions,.educational tools, and outreach strategies, which will enhance orangutan population management, local.community environment stewardship and health of the people, wildlife, and the environment. Project.objectives include: (1) Implement an effective orangutan conservation strategy by continuing to.reintroduce and monitor a reinforced orangutan population and their habitat in BBBRNP; (2) Through an.integrated approach, implement a conservation and environmental education and outreach strategy to.strengthen local capacity, enhance environmental stewardship and community engagement in orangutan.and habitat conservation; and (3) Through a Planetary Health approach, implement an outreach and.zoonotic disease control strategy to reduce the risk of epidemics and threats to orangutans and other.wildlife at human-wildlife interfaces around the BBBRNP area.

title.narrative: SUMATRAN RHINO PROTECTION IN THE CORE AREA OF THE WESTERN LEUSER ECOSYSTEM

description.narrative: The primary goal of this project is to maintain a zero-poaching rate and a sustained increase in the population of Sumatran rhinos.in the western Leuser Ecosystem. The project objectives and activities are as follows: (1) Wildlife Protection Teams (WPT) and.post patrol teams equipped with basic gear, such as field clothing, tents, GPS units, and cameras, and providing Spatial.Monitoring and Reporting Tool (SMART) patrol training; (2) Four Wildlife Protection Teams mobilized and reporting on data.including rhino signs, report violations to police, produce reports on all WPT patrols; (3) Four patrol posts planned, approved and.constructed; and (4) Four post patrols activated and reporting on data.

title.narrative: CONSERVING BORNEAN ORANGUTANS IN PRIMARY, DISTURBED AND CUSTOMARY FORESTS IN GUNUNG PALUNG NATIONAL PARK, INDONESIA, AND THE SURROUNDING LANDSCAPE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) apply the use of drone technology, including newly available thermal drones, to assess orangutan populations, locate individual animals and assess canopy temperature, and build a photographic database of orangutan nests from a drones perspective; pilot the use of thermal.equipped drones as a method for locating orangutans; implement the use of thermal-equipped drones to rapidly assess orangutan presence in protected Customary Forest areas; and assess canopy temperature using thermal-equipped drones as a measure of degradation and fire risk; (2) Determine and monitor levels of biodiversity and anthropogenic disturbance in primary, degraded and customary forest habitats; investigate differences in biodiversity and orangutan behavior between forest habitats through camera trapping; expand bio-acoustic monitoring in degraded and primary habitats; investigate differences in phenology of trees and lianas in primary, disturbed and Customary Forests; determine differences in rainfall, temperature, humidity and solar radiation across primary and disturbed forests as a measure of anthropogenic disturbance and an indicator of forest fire risk; (3) Understand the impact of human disturbance, activity and proximity on orangutan behavior, diet, and health in different forest types present in the Gunung Palung National Park (GPNP) landscape; determine individual identity of orangutans utilizing primary, degraded and customary forest habitats; establish a semi-permanent camp at the Rangkong Research Site; determine differences in orangutan range use and behavior in degraded vs. primary forest types; determine differences in orangutan diet in primary, degraded and customary forests; measure health and parasite load of orangutans found in the Rangkong and Cabang Panti sites; (4) assist the Tanjung Gunung community decrease their dependence on environmentally destructive activities, switching to more sustainable livelihoods and becoming environ

title.narrative: SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN (PONGO ABELII) REINTRODUCTION, POPULATION RESEARCH AND ENHANCING COMMUNITY CONSERVATION STEWARDSHIP ACEH, INDONESIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is, by the end of 2024, to release at least 160 individual orangutans in Jantho.Nature Reserve (24 orangutans released during the project period) and to protect and reduce illegal.activities in Jantho Nature Reserve. Project objectives include the following: (1) Rehabilitated Sumatran.orangutans are released and monitored in Jantho Nature Reserve; (2) Jantho Nature Reserve (16,000 ha).is protected by the addition of a second patrol team, and ranger capacities are enhanced, by ensuring.monthly patrol missions take place, Community Ranger training takes place, at least 2 events per year.covering subjects including reptile/mammal surveying methods, SMART (Spatial Monitoring and.Reporting Tool) datasheet formats, GPS training, single rope climbing, and first aid; and (3) The six.project communities are informed and engaged in actions to protect local forest biodiversity, including.Sumatran orangutans.

title.narrative: USING HEALTHCARE AND CONSERVATION INCENTIVES TO PROTECT ORANGUTAN HABITAT IN INDONESIAN BORNEO -- CYCLE 12: RESTORING RAINFOREST ECOSYSTEMS AND SUPPORTING SUSTAINABLE ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOODS

description.narrative: The primary goal of this project is to conserve and restore Bornean orangutan habitat in West Kalimantan through healthcare and conservation incentives, reforestation, and supporting a just transition from logging to sustainable alternative livelihoods. Project objectives include, (1) Expand regenerative farming training opportunities and increase support for alternative livelihoods for former loggers; (2) Provide high-quality, affordable healthcare as an incentive to protect orangutan habitat; (3) Restore 72 hectares of orangutan habitat through reforestation; and (4) Increase biodiversity monitoring to identify and protect critical orangutan habitat.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to support the reintroduction and protection of new, fully wild, viable populations of Bornean.orangutans, by effectively expanding reintroduction and post-release monitoring, as well as strengthening the capacities of local.government and neighboring communities to conserve the newly-established orangutan populations and their habitat. title.narrative: PROTECTING AND MONITORING THE SUMATRAN TIGER POPULATION OF THE BUKIT TIGA PULUH NATIONAL PARK IN SUMATRA, INDONESIA.

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to (1) Conduct joint patrols between park rangers and community-based scouts; (2) Implement.SMART (Spatial Monitoring and Reporting Tool) patrols and provide law enforcement training to significantly reduce tiger.poaching, illegal logging, and forest encroachment; (3) Monitor tigers and their habitat to assess the health of the ecosystem and.conservation status throughout the project lifespan; (4) Secure the livelihood of traditional and indigenous communities in a.specific area inside the national park as a safeguard against continuous forest encroachment in favor of farm land; (5) Build.capacity of traditional communities to sustainably implement environmentally-friendly agroforestry inside the Bukit Tiga Puluh.National Park; and (6) Support traditional communities inside the Bukit Tiga Puluh National Park with market access for non.timber forest products.

title.narrative: PROTECTING BORNEAN ORANGUTANS, WHITE-BEARDED GIBBONS, AND THE ABBOTT S GRAY GIBBONS THROUGH A COMMUNITY-LED APPROACH IN WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PRESERVE THREE ENDANGERED PRIMATE SPECIES BY IMPROVING THE WELL-BEING OF 2,000 INDIGENOUS VILLAGERS LIVING NEAR THE GUNUNG NIYUT NATURE RESERVE AND THE GUNUNG NANING PROTECTION FORESTS OF WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) SUPPORT LOCALLY LED DETERRENTS TO THREATS TO PRIMATE SPECIES AT PROJECT SITES (2) IMPROVE LOCAL COMMUNITY WELL-BEING TO REDUCE DEPENDENCY ON ILLEGAL ENVIRONMENTAL ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING SUPPORT OF LIVELIHOOD DEVELOPMENT AND DIVERSIFICATION THROUGH A CONSERVATION COOPERATIVES VILLAGE SAVINGS AND LOANS (VSL) PROGRAM FOR NEW VILLAGES IN BOTH SITES AND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT TRAINING, MONTHLY HOUSEHOLD VISITS BY HEALTH AMBASSADORS AT BOTH SITES, FACILITATING AND SUPPORTING TRAVELING CLINICS TO PARTNER VILLAGES IN BOTH SITES AND (3) STABILIZE POPULATIONS OF THREE ENDANGERED PRIMATE SPECIES THREATENED BY FOREST LOSS AND POACHING, BY CONDUCTING ANNUAL SURVEYS TO ESTIMATE POPULATION DENSITIES OF TARGETED PRIMATE SPECIES AT BOTH SITES, AND SUPPORT COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO REFOREST DEGRADED FOREST LANDS WITH NATIVE PLANT SPECIES IN THE GUNUNG NIYUT SITE.

title.narrative: PROTECTING BORNEAN ORANGUTANS, WHITE-BEARDED GIBBONS, AND THE ABBOTT S GRAY GIBBONS THROUGH A COMMUNITY-LED APPROACH IN WEST KALIMANTAN, INDONESIA

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to preserve three endangered primate species by improving the well-being of 2,000 indigenous.villagers living near the Gunung Niyut Nature Reserve and the Gunung Naning protection forests of West Kalimantan, Indonesia..Project objectives include, (1) Support locally led deterrents to threats to primate species at project sites; (2) Improve local.community well-being to reduce dependency on illegal environmental activities, including support of livelihood development and.diversification through a Conservation Cooperatives Village Savings and Loans (VSL) Program for new villages in both sites and.financial management training, monthly household visits by Health Ambassadors at both sites, facilitating and supporting.traveling clinics to partner villages in both sites; and (3) Stabilize populations of three endangered primate species threatened by.forest loss and poaching, by conducting annual surveys to estimate population densities of targeted primate species at both sites,.and support community members to reforest degraded forest lands with native plant species in the Gunung Niyut site.

title.narrative: CONSERVATION OF THE CRITICALLY ENDANGERED ROTE ISLAND SNAKE-NECKED TURTLE

description.narrative: The purpose of this project is to help conserve the Rote-Island snake-necked turtles in Indonesia which is likely extinct in the wild.due to trafficking for the pet trade and habitat loss and deterioration of its native lake habitat. Activities include: (1) transferring.captive held turtles from Singapore to Kupang, Indonesia to establish a captive breeding program; (2) developing a management.plan with stakeholders for restoration of lake habitat and reestablishment of wild populations; (3) reassessing the readiness of.three potential release sites, and (4) conducting the first release trials.

title.narrative: GENETIC ANALYSIS OF SUMATRAN AND JAVAN RHINOCEROS BY INDONESIAN RESEARCHERS II

description.narrative: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A BROAD SAMPLING FOR DUNG SAMPLES FOR BOTH SPECIES, AND TO DEVELOP NOVEL METHODS TO IMPROVE DNA PRESERVATION FROM DUNG, BETTER IDENTIFY DISTINCT MATERNAL LINEAGES, AND IDENTIFY SIRE LINEAGES. GRANTEE WILL INITIATE A PROJECT TO STORE AND GROW CELLS, TO ALLOW FOR EXTRACTION OF HIGH-QUALITY DNA AND TO ENABLE IN VITRO AND GENOMIC STUDIES ON A LONGER-TERM BASIS. THE PROJECT EXPECTS FOR EACH SPECIES 1 WIDESPREAD SAMPLING OF DUNG FROM WILD RHINOS 2 DEVELOPMENT OF IMPROVED DUNG COLLECTION METHODS 3 HIGH THROUGHPUT SEQUENCING HTS TO BE USED ON DNA FROM DUNG SAMPLES 4 MATERNAL LINEAGES IDENTIFIED MORE ACCURATELY AND PRECISELY BY EXTRACTING FULL MITOGENOMES FROM HTS THE HTS READS WILL ALSO IDENTIFY DIET AND PATHOGENS AND 5 NOVEL Y-CHROMOSOME HAPLOTYPE MARKERS DEVELOPED AND USED TO IDENTIFY PATERNAL LINEAGES. THE NEXT-GENERATION SEQUENCES FROM DUNG SAMPLES WILL PERMIT RHINOCEROS DIET AND INTESTINAL PARASITES TO BE EXAMINED. THE RESULTS OF THIS STUDY WILL CONTRIBUTE TO A GROWING BODY OF GENOMIC REFERENCES OF SOUTHEAST ASIAN FLORA, WHICH WILL BE SHARED WITH ECOLOGICAL RESEARCHERS AND PROVIDE VITAL INFORMATION TO HABITAT RESTORATION EFFORTS LOCALLY.

title.narrative: PROTECTION OF SUMATRAN ORANGUTAN (PONGO ABELII) POPULATIONS AND THEIR HABITATS IN KETAMBE, SORAYA AND SUAQ RESEARCH STATIONS WESTERN LEUSER ECOSYSTEM

description.narrative: THE PRIMARY GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE COMMUNITY PROTECTION SYSTEM FOR ORANGUTANS AND THEIR FOREST HABITAT AROUND THE KETAMBE, SUAQ BELIMBING AND SORAYA RESEARCH STATIONS BY ESTABLISHING AND ENHANCING COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS THAT ENGAGE IN PARTICIPATORY FOREST PATROL AND FOREST RESTORATION. PROJECT OBJECTIVES INCLUDE, (1) TRAINING OF COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS (2) EQUIP AND SUPPORT COMMUNITY PATROL TEAMS BY PROVIDING THE TEAMS WITH BASIC FIELD GEAR SUCH AS TENTS, FIELD CLOTHING, RAINCOATS, GPS UNITS, ETC. (3) COMMUNITY PATROLS AND REDUCE ILLEGAL ACTIVITY (4) FOREST RESTORATION IN ORANGUTAN HABITAT AND (5) ORANGUTAN MONITORING IN KETAMBE AND SORAYA.
